threads.com:
Why You Should Copy Anime:
https://i.imgur.com/zNDsyF0.jpg
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kbKqIJcIUCw
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dgjx6y6B_G8

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.
>Don’t copy recklessly. Use construction, color theory, and other fundamental concepts to rehearse a drawing process that you can later easily manipulate for original artwork.
>Post all of your anime studies. Post even when you’re told not to. Create an art community that actually draws and improves together instead of just talking about it.
>Number your attempts and link to your previous posts.
>Critiquers should lead by example by posting their studies.

General Anime Style Discussion:
>Questions about achieving certain styles/techniques/compositions etc.
>Drawing methods, study habits, resources, tutorials, tools, software, etc
>Be specific and try to post a sample of your study attempts before asking for help.

**Draw copies from good anime styled references to mindfully up our mileage, internalize appealing aesthetics, and learn from each other’s processes and knowledge.**

Recommended Resources:
https://pastebin.com/Yz2scAEc

>>6388502
Don’t say things with art. Good art that says things happens accidentally. The parts of your mind that will give you the most original content can’t be accessed consciously. Tap into subconscious desires by free drawing. I start drawing a rabbit and as I draw it turns into a dead goat - why? Then the goat is carrying a key - why? I don’t know at first, but as soon as I finish, it becomes obvious, and pretty soon I have a piece that seems to be about finding meaning in death.

threads.com: I busted my ass for 5 years , was living as a neet obsessing over becoming a pro artist and destroyed my health and sanity. Last year i got an entry level job at the local branch of a big studio as a junior concept artist. My coworkers are great , working conditions are pretty good and pay is also good. However i fucking hate it . We are barely artists , just some recyclers of already x100 recycled generic "art". At this point i feel that the majority of concept "artists" and illustrators simply could be replaced by ai and leave the art director to do the tweaks. I believe the end of art is near, everything that we could imagine is already done and oversaturated to the t. I deeply regret getting into this field and not leaving it as a simple hobby. I'm leaving my resignation letter after news year and going to uni. (thank god i'm 24)

last_replies.com:
Whats the difference between using linseed oil vs paint thinner for thinning oil paints?
Everything I can find online seems to talk about them interchangeably, is there a reason to use one over the other?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6390809
+linseed oil makes the paint have more oil (oil to pigment ratio increases) slower drying, more gloss, not as easy to paint over dry, harder for atmospheric vapors and moisture to penetrate, more yellowing, more flexible, used for glazes
+paint thinner makes makes the oil thinner (oil to pigment ratio remains the same but effectively lower since it also breaks down oil) leaner and thinner paint layer, more matte surface, pigment can be unbound if thinned too much, more susceptible to dirt and moisture penetration due to microscopic pores, faster drying, mostly used for under layers

threads.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

So what is the best clay for sculpting.

I think Chavant is. I tried to use monster clay however it is so trash.
1) it is hard.
2) Even after you warm it up there are like 4 states that are to hot and 2 who are OK 1 that is to hard and then you get into hard and super hard that you can not work with.
3) needing extra tools like heat guns and flames to heat up your metal tools is not fun

I think YT and everyone on it is engaged in some psychological operation to shill monster clay.

I do not know why people are so hyped about monster clay ? It is extremely hard to work with, I did have the medium monster clay fora long time and I give up. The thing is super hard to work with and simply stupid the elastic nature hinders you working with it.
Like you can not even get details in because the damn thing is pulling the rest of the clay with itself. and after it cools it is only OK-ish for a short time then it gets to hard and the ultimate hardness is basically unworkable crap.

There is only 1 channel who tells you that monster clay is crap and to use Chavant and that one is trying to sell you real sculpting lessons.

Chavant is great fun to work with no need to warm up. .

I'm not fucken buying more tools like heat guns and heating lamps to try to see if monster clay is great. I simply give up and I hate the red color of monster clay.

Chavant gray is the best color and the best clay.

Also I do not give a shit about making permanent statues I simply scrap my work and make a different sculpture, I save money and have no need for more crap in my house.

I looked on YT for the videos I was talking about and it looks like they got deleted when we started teaching for NMA or the other school he does shit for. :/ He is really good if you can find anything of his online.

Have you tried using a crock pot to keep your clay warm and workable? You can get them used for cheap and just use it for your clay so you don't ruin your microwave.

I definitely feel your frustration with monster clay, man. But it is really good especially for high detail sculpts. Chavant is nice for just learning and busting out sculpts for practice but it is a little too workable, just putting your hands on it the wrong way can fuck up a sculpt. I used foil balled up inside the armature so it would keep its form and it still was a struggle. I've seen others that were determined to use it and did well with it, I just can't unless it's for practice only.

As far as tools go, home made rakes are the best, just get something to use as a handle and put large wire in a loop, wrap smaller wire around that, and attach it to your handle. Better than any store bought rake. Silicone tools are nice for smoothing and doing detail work but they're not necessary.

Your rendering has ver little feeling of form because there value range is too narrow. If we take the colors away and put them next to each other it is easy to see that they are very similar greys. Picking colors that are further apart can help with this problem.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6393484
to explain this even more clearly I did a color picking on the values of the hat and checked them on the color wheel. Their value is between 56 and 46 out of 100 which means that you are using only 10% of the values available to you to show all lights and shadows on the hat. I didn't check the others but they are similarly low. For starters try to use around 30%-50% of the values and you should see improvement

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
it was art that was made under the influence of the french academies which valued classicism, but of a different sort than the classicism of renaissance.
in the current era, it is now mostly severe naturalism often associated with bargue method and long pose studio works with no context. I suppose some painters can do more than that, but their more complex works still often show that their mind goes back to figure drawing studio setting, with the same kind of lighting employed in moderns studios and the same kind of meaningless poses that you see professional figure drawing class models for hire do.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Would you look at it for longer than one second?
threads.com:
No matter how much skill you got, how many years, decades of experience, how long you spend drawing it, how many hours, days, weeks, how unique your designs are, how personal it is for you or even how generic and trendy you made it, people won't fucking look at it for longer than one second.
Neat. Swipe. Like. Click away. Bookmark. NEXT!
You would do the same.
Everyone is an artist and art is everywhere. Infinite supply makes the value of a single piece nearly worthless. People spend more time reading the text in the balloons than looking at the art in the comic. More time reading the tweet than looking at the image embedded in the tweet. Even the most successful professionals only get a tiny bit more attention per person per drawing than a teenager who picked up the pencil yesterday and posted a stick figure.
Anyone else feels the same way?
I used to draw lots for fun, but when I think if I posted something on the internet it wouldn't captivate a single person, drawing feels meaningless. What is the point? Upload this and it's just a waste of space in someone's servers. A waste of data and of time.
In thousands of illustrations I have seen only a handful made me stop and look for longer than one second. This is my goal now. I'll study them to figure out what they did different and maybe I'll realize something and be able to do the same. If I can make people stop clicking and pause just to stare what I drew, I'll know I've made it.
I guess this makes me an attention whore. Maybe sovl comes from drawing what you want and not from caring about what other people think. But then what if "what I want" is to make others feel the same way I was made feel those handful of times?

Art styles, processes, line style, shapes, forms, color, no color, paint, canvas, digital, pen and ink doodling, 2d, 3d, pixel art, anime, realism, abstract, the list is endless. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6389403
You're caught up in the deceptive vocabulary of "people appreciate a painting by looking at it, therefore I will measure appreciation by the time spent looking". I believe this is simply incorrect. The appreciation of a piece of art remains long after the actual viewing.

Consider the medium of animation, where the average drawing is only seen for 1/12th of a second, and yet they come together to form a greater meaning. Better yet, consider movies. People can watch a movie for like 2 hours and then remember it and treasure it for years. That's an insanely positive ratio if you ask me. I believe that the job of a painter is practically the same. You're not creating individual pieces, but rather a general "spirit". When someone looks at one of your painting, they receive some of your spirit. If they like it, they will come back for more, and with each new painting you give them more of this spirit until you've created a powerful and long lasting impression with your body of work. It's cumulative.

And of course, there is still the possibility of creating a painting so powerful that it can live in people's heads rent free for years after having only seen it a few times, such as pic related.

This is basically just my drunk and convoluted way of asking you to reevaluate this arbitrary and slapdash conception of what the appreciation of art is and how it works. If your post was true then people probably wouldn't be creating and connecting with art as much as they are. So go out there and observe how this shit actually works, unbiased, and find your way once you have a more clear grasp of it.

We're not really closer today than we were 10 years ago. Maybe with the exception for Rebelles pigment mixing, but the actual brush tools haven't improved in a decade+ since dual brush and the mixer brush were introduced in PS. 3d graphics and other CGI production tools are improving at breakneck speeds but digital painting is completely stagnated. Why?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6392021
There are a lot of reasons.
First off, there's the fact that when working in trad you're manipulating 3-D materials. Trad media are physical things. Mimicking simpler media like graphite, charcoal, ink, marker, and even watercolor to an extent isn't so hard, since the pigments or dyes are only applied in a relatively thin layer on the drawing surface and their interactions are fairly simple to emulate with some exceptions (which I'll get to shortly). However, when you're getting into anything that has to do with applying pigment with a bristle brush, especially paints that you can layer and apply thick globs of to the canvas, and of which its properties change when wet or dry, a 2D pixel-manipulation-based engine probably isn't going to cut it. Paint is a 3D medium, a physical fluid, and for truly accurate emulation, would most likely need to be simulated and modeled in 3D. The pigment mixing you mentioned is only a small step in that direction, and very few programs support that- to my knowledge, only Rebelle 5, MyPaint, and an obscure paint app for iOS devices (developed by the same guy responsible for the pigment mixing algorithm in MyPaint) even have this feature.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6392682
(Cont'd) Furthermore, the very hardware that we use to interface with digital art programs are flawed to begin with. Putting aside the fact that we're interacting with a flat, textureless 2D screen, our only tool for drawing and painting is a pen with a plastic nib. How can you adequately emulate a brush, laden with ink or paint, with that? You really can't.
Digital mimicking traditional is a niche thing. The old stamp brush paradigm ain't broke, so few people care to fix it. Most are fine with digital painting being its own flavor and don't feel the need for it to really emulate traditional. However, digital pigment mixing does seem like a very good step forward which has been received very well by all who have tried it, since it allows for intuitive on-canvas mixing that results in much more rich and vibrant colors. Hopefully we'll see it become a standard feature in other digital painting programs in the future, especially in the FOSS software space.

threads.com: How does one paint values in the shadow area? What principle do values adhere to in diffused light?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6392260
>Value groups are a part of keying your painting.
>You don't need to do any of this,
Traditional painters did because they had to mix their colors in advance and had to make sure the painting would read well.

If your painting reads fine then you don't need to worry about value groups.


>I've just found that this method of value study gives good insight to beginners very fast.
Good for you if starting by finding the two most extreme values works for you. Your goal should be not needing to do that though.

It is a little like if you do line work and then need to start by placing down the thickest and thinnest line first. I mean, sure. If that works for you.

Painting (and drawing) should be a fluid process where you just have fun. You will want to eliminate as many mechanical processes from that experience as possible. A single value stroke or added highlight near the end is often enough to change how an entire image reads.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
I'm currently using cadmium red, cadmium yellow pale and ultramarine blue (plus burnt umber) on my palette mostly for portraits but also some landscapes. But I find the intensity of these colours is too saturated for every application and so have to spend time mixing them down... not to mention the cost of cadmium colors.

Is there a low chroma alternative for these colors which will cover all the bases without the added cost and labor?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
white either lead or titanium, no zinc
yellow ocher
raw sienna
burnt sienna (brownish red in mass tone, a bright brick color in glazes)
red earths of your choice
raw umber
carbon black of our choice

optional low cost pigments
nicosia green earth (appears somewhat a greenish blue with white, translucent)
violet ochre/violet hematite (subtle violet tints)

Reserve cadmium colors and ultramarine for when you need something saturated. Using high cost saturated pigments only to make them gray or brown is a waste in my expert and poorfag opinion.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6390930
Thanks for that.

Do you think Prussian Blue or Indigo would work as well?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6391185

NTA but prussian blue is a really, really strong tinter, so i don't think that works if you're looking for low chroma colors.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6391185
synthetic ultramarine blue is cheap enough that you don't need much other unless you are doing historical pigments. yes, prussian blue is highly tinting and there's not much uses for it unless you use that specific color in your paintings a lot or you use it in strange mixes.
if you don't need a blueish green you can also drop nicosia green earth. if you need a green and don't want to buy the more expensive synthetic green pigments like cadmium, cobalt, chromium or viridian, there are other green earths. some lower chroma olive green, and some that are bright and more yellow, depending on where they are from and manufacturer
choice also depends on if you care about things like transparency and opacity.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>6391185
i don't have experience with indigo to say. it's in the same price range as synthetic ultramarine but it's less chromatic so maybe you can use it instead. most of the ones on the market are a mix of ultramarine blue and one or two other pigments.

>also funny thing, i used to think that 104% srgb was a good thing (higher number good!). then i realized it's just a wildly inaccurate SRGB. same with wide gamut.
Not necessarily, as I wrote above it depends what you want to display your data on. If you're intending the data for different devices with larger gamut sRGB can be a severe limitation.
If the gamut of the work-monitor is larger than the gamut of the intended display-device on the other hand you will simply have to have the correct .icc monitor profile installed in order for the software to know how to display the data. The example of 104% sRGB is however a point where a 100% clean sRGB would make more sense as the gain is little and you're introducing a lot more variables.

>CSP is getting a new version soon, maybe they'll adress this?
Unlikely, it's a problem we had before budget-workstations were overclocked dual Celeron 300A s .. one core per CPU, and mainstream multi-core CPUs have been around since 2006. If the lack of the multi-threaded smudge-tool has not been addressed for 20 years it's unlikely to suddenly happen next month.

last_replies.com:
>>6382214
painting ugly (upclose)
> Some artists seem to render subjects very accurately but still not achieve this effect?

This is because they try to paint every little detail which is not how your eyes/brain actually sees and processes the world.

If you've ever seen a sargent painting in real life, when you stand at a distance it looks incredible. But when you get upclose the illusion stops working and it looks almost abstract from how loose and undefined the brush strokes are.

so basically
>don't try to "fix" WHILE you are putting in your colors, do that after.
>use a color checker (you would be surprised how unsaturated and dark colors actually are in real life)

another reason might be that by not adding needless detail, your brain fills in the blanks which is closer to what happens you look at things IRL, so its more interesting to look at.

THE BIGGEST REASON VERY IMPORTANT:

Your brain is wired to love abstraction, because nature is abstract. When you look at a beautiful tree, you arent paying attention to the detail on every single leaf all at once.
The tree does not plan its leaves out in the same exact way everytime.

Zoom into pic related, you will see how much of it looks pretty much like random crap, but its still pleasing to look at.
This painting looks so real, but the detail is just not there in most areas.

If you zoom into the best realist paintings, I can guarantee every spot you choose could look like its own abstract painting
